senses.ex: You are subject to the rules of the game.

Tips.title: Rule Bound
Tips.description: Use 'subject to' to convey necessity to follow established rules.
Tips.example: When playing chess, you are subject to the movement rules of each piece.

Tips.title: Not Optional
Tips.description: 'Subject to' highlights that certain conditions are not optional within a system.
Tips.example: All passengers are subject to a security check before boarding.

senses.ex: The event is subject to the weather.

Tips.title: Uncertainty Factor
Tips.description: 'Subject to' can indicate that plans might change due to factors like weather.
Tips.example: The picnic is subject to cancellation if it rains.

Tips.title: Plan Flexibly
Tips.description: Remember, 'subject to' suggests you should be prepared for adjustments.
Tips.example: Flight schedules are subject to change without prior notice.

senses.de: Possible or liable to be influenced or affected by
senses.ex: The coastal town is subject to flooding.

Tips.title: Likelihood of Effect
Tips.description: 'Subject to' implies a high probability of being affected by something, like a natural event.
Tips.example: Crops in this region are subject to damage by early frosts.

Tips.title: Risk Awareness
Tips.description: It's used to make someone aware of potential risks or effects.
Tips.example: This area is subject to high levels of pollution.

senses.de: Liable to or required to give
senses.ex: You will be subject to penalties if you break the law.

Tips.title: Legal Obligations
Tips.description: In legal contexts, 'subject to' refers to compliance with laws or regulations.
Tips.example: Tenants are subject to the terms of their lease agreements.

Tips.title: Consequences
Tips.description: Emphasizes that failure to comply may result in consequences or penalties.
Tips.example: Driving over the speed limit means you are subject to fines.
